case_name: State of Saurashtra v. the respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 182 of 1955 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 182 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated February 26, 1954 of Saurashtra High Court in Civil Miscellaneous Application No. 52 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 26, 1954, of the former Saurashtra High Court in Civil Miscella

facts.text: Judgment delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J. on September 25, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. September 25. The Judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-This is an appeal against

facts.text: Respondent appointed in 1948 as Memandari, Superintendent of State Guest Houses, in State of Junagadh administered by Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was appointed in 1948 Memandari, that is, Superintendent of State Guest Houses, in what was the State

facts.text: Respondent was later confirmed in the appointment.

anchor.surface_text: of Junagadh when it was administered by the Government of India, and was, later on, companyfirmed in that appointment.

facts.text: In 1949, Junagadh integrated into State of Saurashtra.

anchor.surface_text: In 1949, Junagadh became integrated into the State of Saurash- tra, and, thereafter, the services of the respondent were

facts.text: Services of respondent continued by State of Saurashtra and appointed to various posts.

anchor.surface_text: companytinued by that State, and he was appointed from time to time to various posts.

facts.text: On June 15, 1950, respondent appointed Sales Tax Officer, Madhya Saurashtra, Rajkot.

anchor.surface_text: On June 15, 1950, he was appointed Sales Tax Officer, Madhya Saurashtra, Rajkot, and was company- firmed in that post

facts.text: Respondent confirmed as Sales Tax Officer on April 16, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: on April 16, 1952. On October 30, 1952, the Government of Saurashtra, purporting to act under Gov- ernment Resolution

facts.text: On October 30, 1952, Government of Saurashtra passed order compulsorily terminating respondent's services under Government Resolution No. 60 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On October 30, 1952, the Government of Saurashtra, purporting to act under Gov- ernment Resolution No. 60 of 1948 as it then stood, passed an order companypulsorily terminating his services.

facts.text: Respondent filed writ application in High Court of Saurashtra challenging the termination order.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon filed a writ application in the High companyrt of Saurashtra, challenging the validity of this order

facts.text: Saurashtra High Court set aside the termination order dated October 30, 1952, holding it was dismissal without enquiry, violating Art. 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that it was made without any numberice to him of any charge of misconduct or inefficiency and without any en- quiry, and was, in companysequence in companytravention of Art. 311 2 .

facts.text: Appeal preferred to Supreme Court on certificate under Art. 133(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been preferred against their judgment and order on a certificate under Art. 133 1  c .

facts.text: Respondent was 50 years old on October 30, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplaint of the respondent is that he was only 50 on October 30, 1952,

facts.text: Rule 161 of Bombay Civil Services Rules adopted by Saurashtra: compulsory retirement at age 55 for non-inferior servants.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 161 of the Bombay Civil Services Rules, which Rules had been adopted by the State of Saurashtra with some modifications, runs as follows Except as otherwise provided in the other clauses of this rule, the date of companypulsory retirement of a Government servant,, other than an inferior servant, is the date on which he attains the age of 55 years.

facts.text: Respondent was not an inferior servant.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated that the respondent Was number an inferior servant, and this rule was therefore applicable to him.

facts.text: Rule 165-A amended by Saurashtra Government on September 28, 1950 and January 15, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Rule No. 165-A, however, was amended by the Saurashtra Government on September 28, 1950, and again on January 15, 1952,

facts.text: Amended R. 165-A allowed Government to retire servant after 25 years qualifying service or 50 years age without reason, exercised in public interest like inefficiency.

anchor.surface_text: and on the relevant date, the rule, as amended and omitting what is number material, stood as follows Government is pleased to direct that the proviso and the Note to Bombay Civil Services Rule 165-A shall number apply to the servants of this Government.

facts.text: Termination order made under amended R. 165-A as respondent had completed 50 years.

anchor.surface_text: It was under this rule that the order was statedly made on October 30, 1952, and as the respondent had companypleted the age of 50 on that date,

facts.text: Supreme Court held order of compulsory retirement is not dismissal or removal under Art. 311(2), citing Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Since the above decision was given, the question whether an order of companypulsory retirement was one of dismissal or removal within Art. 311 2  came up for companysideration in this Court in Shyam Lal v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1 , and it was held that such an order did number amount to one of dis- missal or removal within the meaning of that Article,

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court order, dismissed respondent's petition.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order of the lower Court is set aside, and the petition of the respondent is dismissed.

facts.text: Respondent contended in High Court that retirement order was dismissal requiring Art. 311(2) compliance.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the stand taken by the respondent in the Court below was that an order retiring an officer before the age of superannuation was in substance one of dismissal or removal and must, in order to be valid, satisfy the requirements of Art. 311 2 ,

facts.text: No claim raised in writ petition about age of superannuation being 60 under Junagadh rules.

anchor.surface_text: But numbersuch, claim was put forward in the writ petition, and it is number too late to raise it.
This appeal has been preferred against their judgment and order on a certificate under Art. 133 1  c .

anchor.surface_text: Rule 161 of the Bombay Civil Services Rules, which Rules had been adopted by the State of Saurashtra with some modifications, runs as follows Except as otherwise provided in the other clauses of this rule, the date of compulsory retirement of a Government servant,, other than an inferior servant, is the date on which he attains the age of 55 years.

anchor.surface_text: that an order retiring an officer before the age of superannuation was in substance one of dismissal or removal and must, in order to be valid, satisfy the requirements of Art. 311 2 , and that R. 165-A, in so far as it authorised the Government to terminate the service without any reason and without any enquiry was repugnant to Art. 311 2 , and was therefore ultra vires.

holdings.text: The real criterion for deciding whether an order terminating the services of a servant is one of dismissal or removal is to ascertain whether it involves any loss of benefits previously earned. Applying this test, an order under R. 165-A cannot be held to be one of dismissal or removal.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the real criterion for deciding whether an order terminating the services of a servant is one of dismissal or removal is to ascertain whether it involves any loss of benefits previously earned. Applying this test, an order under R. 165-A cannot be held to be one of dismissal or removal,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ratio decidendi from Shyam Lal case: dismissal/removal involves punishment and loss of accrued benefits like pension; compulsory retirement does not.

holdings.text: R. 165-A is not violative of Art. 311(2) and is intra vires.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of opinion that R. 165-A is not violative of Art. 311(2) and is intra vires, and that the impugned order dated October 30, 1952, passed in exercise of the power conferred thereby is valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule authorizes retirement without enquiry as it is not punishment under Art. 311(2); no loss of benefits, follows Shyam Lal.

holdings.text: The impugned order dated October 30, 1952, passed in exercise of the power conferred by R. 165-A is valid.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of opinion that R. 165-A is not violative of Art. 311(2) and is intra vires, and that the impugned order dated October 30, 1952, passed in exercise of the power conferred thereby is valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order falls within amended R. 165-A as respondent aged 50; rule valid, so order upheld.

holdings.text: The provision in R. 165-A that the power will not be exercised except in cases of misconduct or inefficiency does not alter its character as compulsory retirement nor require formal enquiry under Art. 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: Does it make any difference in the position, as is contended by the respondent, that R. 165-A provides, unlike Note I to art. 465-A in Shyam Lals case 1  that the power is not to be exercised except in cases of misconduct or inefficiency ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Such grounds provide background only, not basis for punishment; no duty for formal enquiry unlike dismissal; explicit in rule but implicit in Shyam Lal rule.

holdings.text: Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh governs the present case; no material difference in rules.

anchor.surface_text: If this decision applies to the present case-and it is the contention of the appellant that it does-then there can be no question but that the order dated October 30, 1952, is valid, and that this appeal must succeed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected respondent's distinction based on wording; same nature as retirement without loss of benefits.

holdings.text: Contention that respondent entitled to superannuation at age 60 under Junagadh rules and Art. XVI Instrument of Accession cannot be entertained as no such claim raised in writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: But no such claim was put forward in the writ petition, and it is not too late to raise it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar: point not pleaded in original petition.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the real criterion for deciding whether an order terminating the services of a servant is one of dismissal or removal is to ascertain whether it involves any loss of benefits previously earned. Applying this test, an order under R. 165-A cannot be held to be one of dismissal or removal,
In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order of the lower Court is set aside, and the petition of the respondent is dismissed.
